awd_titl_txt: High-Fidelity Radiotherapy Treatment Planning via Dimension-Free Zeroth-Order Algorithms
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will contribute to the Nation's health and welfare by improving methods for radiation therapy (radiotherapy) in the treatment of cancer.  Radiotherapy has long been used as a prevalent mode of cancer treatment; its effectiveness lies in using high-energy radiation to eradicate cancer cells while sparing the surrounding normal tissue.  Underlying the delivery of radiotherapy are complex optimization algorithms that determine safe and effective treatment plans.  The creation of accurate treatment plans is difficult due to the high-dimensionality of the problems as well as to uncertainties in individual response to radiation dosage. This project develops methods to improve algorithms that guide the delivery of precise amounts of radiation to target cells.  The research results will be integrated into a continuing medical education program to facilitate collaborations between academics and medical practitioners. To attract recent high school graduates, especially those from under-represented communities, into STEM majors, the project team will participate in the STEPUP outreach program at the University of Florida. 

This project aims to create fundamentally new zeroth-order algorithmic paradigms that are provably capable of mitigating the  The research plan will study variations of randomized gradient-free algorithms that exploit computation-facilitating structures such as sparsity and its generalizations. The project will also derive and analyze algorithms that combine optimization and deep learning methods in solving problems without the knowledge of closed-form formulations. In theory, the computational efficiency of these algorithms is expected to be almost independent of problem dimensionality, up to a logarithmic term. These algorithms will be integrated with the Monte Carlo simulators deemed the gold standard in providing accurate modeling of radiotherapy outcomes. The resulting new treatment planning engines are expected to improve plan fidelity without increasing the computational cost. Extensive experiments and comparisons of the methods will be conducted on realistic cancer treatment data.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project led to advancements to methodologies in zeroth-order optimization, which is useful for high-fidelity radiotherapy treatment planning, in order to reduce the computational effort in large-scale problem instances. Results of this effort provided baseline for further investigation into methods in optimization, machine learning, simulation, and artificial intelligence. Some components of this project developed prototypes of zeroth-order optimization methods tailored to the real applications of planning radiotherapy treatment of cancer, leading to an expanded toolbox for such planning problems in scenarios where the underlying physics model is cumbersome to evaluate especially when given a high-dimensional planning space.

 

More specifically, through this project, a new zeroth-order optimization algorithm, the stochastic gradient-free algorithm with sparse per-iteration updates (SGF-SPIU), was developed to enhance system performance in scenarios where only input-output data are available. This algorithm was theoretically shown to perform consistently when the dimension of the problem became massive and validated in simulations and real-world cases of radiotherapy treatment planning. In both theory and experiments, SGF-SPIU outperformed existing benchmarks. Particularly in the realistic case of radiotherapy planning, the problem was focused on optimizing patient’s biological responses in carbon ion radiotherapy, an advanced cancer treatment modality. To this problem, the SGF-SPIU algorithm demonstrated significant efficiency and efficacy, showing this method to be a promising tool in identifying clinically advantageous radiotherapy plans.

 

This project rigorously studied nonconvex regularization for deep learning models and provided theoretical insights on how to overcome overfitting in large-scale deep models trained with data. This nonconvex regularization approach leverages structural characteristics such as sparsity, low-rankness, and low-bit representation, common in data science applications, and provably allows the scale of a data-driven model to be exponential in the number of training sample points. Informed by the theoretical results, a variant of the UNet neural network was successfully implemented to improve dose calculation models in radiotherapy, particularly in MRI-guided radiotherapy. The experiments showed that the UNet variant provided accurate simulation results with reduced computational demand.

 

Building on the theoretical insights related to deep learning, this project revisited the theories of the empirical risk minimization (ERM) framework. The findings showed that under certain benign regularity conditions—like convexity—the model's sample size requirements could be significantly reduced while maintaining the ERM’s out-of-sample performance. This discovery is highly relevant for many data-driven modeling and decision-making problems, because ERM is a foundational scheme that underpin a wide spectrum of tools and technologies enabling machine learning and decision-making under uncertainty.

 

The project developed a learning-to-optimize (L2O) deep learning model to address inverse problems, which have wide applications in medical treatment planning, image analysis, and signal recovery. This L2O model replicates optimization processes and provides near-instantaneous solutions to traditionally computation-intensive problems. Extensive testing in image reconstruction indicated that the L2O model delivers better accuracy and efficiency compared to other methods, demonstrating its potential in complex, high-stakes applications where high computational efficiency is crucial.

 

During this project, multiple activities for education, outreach, and result dissemination was conducted. The project supported Ph.D. dissertations, expanding STEM workforce with specialty in high-dimensional optimization for radiotherapy. The project findings have been incorporated into both graduate and undergraduate courses as examples and course projects. Master’s and undergraduates also participated, gaining experiences with rigorous STEM research. Six high school students joined in a summer research camp co-organized by the principal investigators. This outreach effort offered these students early exposure to STEM research, inspiring interest in STEM fields such as radiotherapy, optimization, and data science. Project outcomes were publicized through invited seminars, professional conference presentations, peer-reviewed journal publications in order to reach a broad general and scientific audience and contribute to the ongoing development of optimization and cancer treatment.
